title: How were creative writing majors treated in Nazi Germany? - Quora

response.answer_text: I think the title of “creative writing” would have likely come under the heading of philosophy, literature, Language Arts, and maybe theology back then. In the case of Nazi Germany, I think it may have found a use in the propaganda department, or one of its many subsections. Perhaps before the war, there might have been an opening found in burgeoning new world of advertising and marketing, or perhaps in the arts, especially the theater. There was, of course, academia for the chosen few. However, after the Nazis came to power, whatever you wrote was subject to the dictates of the State, and in particular, the Department of Enlightenment and Propaganda. Just like artists, writers had to be approved. In order to do so, they had to submit copies of their work and, if approved, obtain a special permit, otherwise they didn’t work. Of course, they were free to “volunteer” for military duty. Speaking of the movies and writing, you might enjoy an interesting book about about the Ufa, the chief movie production company during the Nazis years, and its actors. The book is entitled “Hitler and the Nazi Cult of Celebrity” by Michael Mann. You might also enjoy “Nazi Women: The Attraction of Evil” by Paul Roland, which covers Joseph Goebbels’ relationship with many of the actors and actresses. Lastly, I would be amiss not to recommend “Leni Riefenstahl: A Memoir” by the lady herself. It details a lot about the artists and their relationship with the Nazis, and in particular, Joseph Goebbels. The other book is “Marlene Dietrich: Life And Legend” by Steven Bach.

There were no “creative writing” classes in Nazi Germany, or anywhere in Europe, and probably not even in the USA. “Creative writing” teaching is a postwar invention by private universities who saw the legions of “future writers”, hired one or two achieved writers and took the “future writers’” money gleefully.
